title: Tulsa King Season 2 Episode 6 Review: Navigator
description: Tulsa King Season 2 Episode 6 pops us right in the home stretch of the second season, and the stakes just ‚Ä¶ The post Tulsa King Season 2 Episode 6 Review: Navigator appeared first on TV Fanatic.
author: Carissa Pavlica
excerpt: The sit-down on Tulsa King Season 2 Episode 6 might have led to a death that will have lasting ramifications. Check out our review!
text: Critic's Rating: 4 / 5.04 Tulsa King Season 2 Episode 6 pops us right in the home stretch of the second season, and the stakes just increased even more than anticipated. A sit-down between the three warring factions went well enough that everyone left the meeting with smiles on their faces, but Bill thinks he succumbed to Dwight‚Äôs charms, screwing himself in the process. Cal, the guy with the biggest chip on his shoulder and an insane new business partner, wasn‚Äôt even involved in the process. How could it have solved anything? (Brian Douglas/Paramount+) I was shocked that Tulsa King Season 2 Episode 5 skipped right over the after-effects of Jackie murdering people right under Cal‚Äôs nose. It was even more shocking that he was his usual cocky self with Jackie during ‚ÄúNavigator‚Äù when he already saw what Jackie was capable of doing. Sure, Chickie idiotically took a pistol through TSA (strapped to his leg, no less), and Bill snubbed his nose at Dwight‚Äôs attention to local cuisine, but Cal is the absolute nutter in this scenario. Of all the guys we‚Äôve met so far, it‚Äôs Jackie who scares the hell out of me. He‚Äôs cold-blooded and calculated in ways the others can‚Äôt match. Cal is probably a close second. Neal McDonough has perfected the smile that doesn‚Äôt meet his crystal-blue eyes. His grin is more akin to the Smile movies than sharing genuine feelings with another human being. (Brian Douglas/Paramount+) So how did Manny get sucked into his orbit? Well, money is the answer, but with strings like that attached, I‚Äôd rather fend for myself. Manny mistakenly thought that he had a simpatico relationship with Cal as if Cal was giving him fifty grand out of the goodness of his three-sizes-too-small heart. In my Tulsa King Season 2 Episode 3 review, I noted that Manny should have talked with Dwight about his money issues instead of accepting ‚Äúhelp‚Äù from Cal. What are you a child? Seriously, are you that fucking stupid? Everything in life is transactional. Did you really not know that? ‚Äî Cal Thresher Manny still thinks that Dwight is a bigger threat than Cal, or at least he did before his latest chat with the heartless SOB. That only proves that Manny is a terrible judge of character. There is a lot of that going around on Tulsa King. Is there any way Manny will allow himself to be ‚Äúowned‚Äù by Cal while continually dishing on Dwight‚Äôs activities? I don‚Äôt see how he can. If he seriously thinks Dwight is the more significant threat, it should motivate him to turn on Cal. (Brian Douglas/Paramount+) I don‚Äôt know if Dwight would take him up on it, but it‚Äôs worth asking if he can be a double agent for Dwight while begging and pleading for his life. I‚Äôm a stick-my-head-in-the-sand kind of gal myself, so I‚Äôd play over that potential scenario so long in my head that I‚Äôd probably pay with my life regardless. Hopefully, Manny isn‚Äôt the same. Manny is tied to Margaret, so killing him would put whoever does it under a microscope in her world. Sometimes, getting the girl is worth the price of a little compassion. The buildup to and the sit-down itself were relatively uneventful. Chickie didn‚Äôt even make the meeting. Vince had no pull whatsoever with either Dwight or Bill, and Dwight charmed the hell out of Bill Bevilaqua. So, things went as you would have imagined. (Brian Douglas/Paramount+) But when the meeting was over, Vince was in trouble with Chickie (who gets more unhinged by the moment), and Bill regretted making a deal with Dwight. I looked up pricing on weed, and here‚Äôs what I found: Low-quality weed typically ranges from $500 to $1,000 per pound, mid-quality weed ranges from $1,000 to $2,500 per pound, and high-quality weed can range from $2,500 to $5,000 or more per pound. There‚Äôs no way Bodhi‚Äôs weed is low-quality. So, assuming that he‚Äôs got high-quality weed that would regularly sell for $3000, $575 a pound seems like a pretty good deal for Bill. That‚Äôs in addition to 15% off the top of the whole operation in return for security and distribution. Bill even got his hands on some fake Ozempics (Is it the mob that‚Äôs selling all the knockoffs on Facebook?), sweetening the deal. (Brian Douglas/Paramount+) I laughed when he told Vince he had heard that the operation went south when Pete died, but he had no idea it was THAT bad. Maybe the Facebook knockoffs are mom-and-pop shops, and the mob steers clear. ü§£ I almost forgot that Joanna is hoping to take the weed shop in a different direction by drop-shipping CBD oil via a website. That‚Äôs big business and a brilliant move. Although Bodhi scoffed at her herb-growing skills in connection with weed, if you‚Äôve got a green thumb, you‚Äôve got a green thumb! Anyway, Dwight‚Äôs a delightful gangster, and he momentarily won Bill over with his talk of local cuisine and milkshakes. Will that last? You‚Äôre different; I‚Äôll give you that much ‚Äî Bill Bevilaqua to Dwight Manfredi I really dig Frank Grillo, and Bill has some redeeming characteristics, unlike Cal. I don‚Äôt want Bill to get back on Dwight‚Äôs bad side because I‚Äôd like to see him stick around for Tulsa King Season 3. (Brian Douglas/Paramount+) Bill‚Äôs operation is more interesting than Cal‚Äôs. Cal is a thug (it made me laugh when he referred to Dwight that way), but Bill has family. He and Dwight could work well together, even if it is long distance. I guess time will tell. While all of this was happening, Tina was taking control of her own and her family‚Äôs safety. She is her father‚Äôs daughter. I don‚Äôt understand how he thought she had The General as a father and wouldn‚Äôt be familiar with mob terms. Apparently, he‚Äôs had his head in the sand, too. Getting a gun is a wise choice, especially since it got her side-by-side with Mitch. I can barely remember her husband, but wasn‚Äôt he a bit of a dolt? (Brian Douglas/Paramount+) Mitch has a good head on his shoulders, and it will be interesting to see how Dwight reacts as Mitch grows closer to Tina. When Mitch said, ‚ÄúShe‚Äôs a beautiful woman; it was my pleasure,‚Äù Dwight did a double take, but he didn‚Äôt overreact. Maybe that‚Äôs a smidgeon of approval. And now we get to the ‚ÄúNavigator.‚Äù Did another Taylor Sheridan show just kill off Michael Beach?? If so, that‚Äôs two in a row where he bit the big one. C‚Äômon, man! But was he killed? I‚Äôm not an explosions expert, but from what I could see of the front seat of the car, it was relatively unaffected. Well, it‚Äôs as unaffected as a blown-up portion of a car could be. It‚Äôs possible he‚Äôll survive, if not only because it‚Äôs too choreographed for Beach to die twice across the Taylor Sheridan universe in such short order. (Brian Douglas/Paramount+) This one will hurt because of how it will affect Tyson. He and his dad have been at odds over his involvement with Dwight for a while now, but this was the first time Mark approved of it. Tyson was so excited to be able to do something for his dad with no strings attached, and he was even more excited when his dad accepted his gift. The worst part will be that Tyson eyeballed that white car before and didn‚Äôt pay enough attention to it. That he recognized it in front of the house shows that he did take note. But why would you take note of a friggin‚Äô Prius? What self-respecting bad guy would be caught dead in one? It makes me wonder if this isn‚Äôt some sort of one-off targeting that has nothing to do with the current situation. (Brian Douglas/Paramount+) Undoubtedly, Tyson will be beating himself up for his part in what happened to his dad. This will be where the rubber meets the road. Any sweetness that remained in Tyson might be gone due to this tragedy. He wanted to step up, and this will push him even further toward that end. Unfortunately, things are only getting more dangerous as time goes on, so he‚Äôll be stepping up at a perilous time ‚Äî assuming Dwight lets him step up under the circumstances. Who put the hit on Dwight? Was it Jackie without Cal‚Äôs assistance? It didn‚Äôt seem there was enough time for Cal, Bill, or Chickie to make the call. Bill and Chickie are still reeling from the results of the sit-down, and Cal is generally unwilling to kill. Where does this shocking turn take us now? If you‚Äôve been enjoying Tulsa King this season, please drop me a comment below to share your thoughts. Username or Email AddressPassword Watch Tulsa King Online
html:
Critic's Rating: 4 / 5.0

4

Tulsa King Season 2 Episode 6 pops us right in the home stretch of the second season, and the stakes just increased even more than anticipated.

A sit-down between the three warring factions went well enough that everyone left the meeting with smiles on their faces, but Bill thinks he succumbed to Dwight‚Äôs charms, screwing himself in the process.

Cal, the guy with the biggest chip on his shoulder and an insane new business partner, wasn‚Äôt even involved in the process. How could it have solved anything?

I was shocked that Tulsa King Season 2 Episode 5 skipped right over the after-effects of Jackie murdering people right under Cal‚Äôs nose.

It was even more shocking that he was his usual cocky self with Jackie during ‚ÄúNavigator‚Äù when he already saw what Jackie was capable of doing.

Sure, Chickie idiotically took a pistol through TSA (strapped to his leg, no less), and Bill snubbed his nose at Dwight‚Äôs attention to local cuisine, but Cal is the absolute nutter in this scenario.

Of all the guys we‚Äôve met so far, it‚Äôs Jackie who scares the hell out of me. He‚Äôs cold-blooded and calculated in ways the others can‚Äôt match.

Cal is probably a close second. Neal McDonough has perfected the smile that doesn‚Äôt meet his crystal-blue eyes. His grin is more akin to the Smile movies than sharing genuine feelings with another human being.

So how did Manny get sucked into his orbit? Well, money is the answer, but with strings like that attached, I‚Äôd rather fend for myself.

Manny mistakenly thought that he had a simpatico relationship with Cal as if Cal was giving him fifty grand out of the goodness of his three-sizes-too-small heart.

In my Tulsa King Season 2 Episode 3 review, I noted that Manny should have talked with Dwight about his money issues instead of accepting ‚Äúhelp‚Äù from Cal.

What are you a child? Seriously, are you that fucking stupid? Everything in life is transactional. Did you really not know that?

‚Äî Cal Thresher

Manny still thinks that Dwight is a bigger threat than Cal, or at least he did before his latest chat with the heartless SOB. That only proves that Manny is a terrible judge of character. There is a lot of that going around on Tulsa King.

Is there any way Manny will allow himself to be ‚Äúowned‚Äù by Cal while continually dishing on Dwight‚Äôs activities? I don‚Äôt see how he can. If he seriously thinks Dwight is the more significant threat, it should motivate him to turn on Cal.

I don‚Äôt know if Dwight would take him up on it, but it‚Äôs worth asking if he can be a double agent for Dwight while begging and pleading for his life.

I‚Äôm a stick-my-head-in-the-sand kind of gal myself, so I‚Äôd play over that potential scenario so long in my head that I‚Äôd probably pay with my life regardless. Hopefully, Manny isn‚Äôt the same.

Manny is tied to Margaret, so killing him would put whoever does it under a microscope in her world. Sometimes, getting the girl is worth the price of a little compassion.

The buildup to and the sit-down itself were relatively uneventful.

Chickie didn‚Äôt even make the meeting. Vince had no pull whatsoever with either Dwight or Bill, and Dwight charmed the hell out of Bill Bevilaqua. So, things went as you would have imagined.

But when the meeting was over, Vince was in trouble with Chickie (who gets more unhinged by the moment), and Bill regretted making a deal with Dwight.

I looked up pricing on weed, and here‚Äôs what I found: Low-quality weed typically ranges from $500 to $1,000 per pound, mid-quality weed ranges from $1,000 to $2,500 per pound, and high-quality weed can range from $2,500 to $5,000 or more per pound.

There‚Äôs no way Bodhi‚Äôs weed is low-quality.

So, assuming that he‚Äôs got high-quality weed that would regularly sell for $3000, $575 a pound seems like a pretty good deal for Bill. That‚Äôs in addition to 15% off the top of the whole operation in return for security and distribution.

Bill even got his hands on some fake Ozempics (Is it the mob that‚Äôs selling all the knockoffs on Facebook?), sweetening the deal.

I laughed when he told Vince he had heard that the operation went south when Pete died, but he had no idea it was THAT bad. Maybe the Facebook knockoffs are mom-and-pop shops, and the mob steers clear. ü§£

I almost forgot that Joanna is hoping to take the weed shop in a different direction by drop-shipping CBD oil via a website. That‚Äôs big business and a brilliant move.

Although Bodhi scoffed at her herb-growing skills in connection with weed, if you‚Äôve got a green thumb, you‚Äôve got a green thumb!

Anyway, Dwight‚Äôs a delightful gangster, and he momentarily won Bill over with his talk of local cuisine and milkshakes. Will that last?

You‚Äôre different; I‚Äôll give you that much

‚Äî Bill Bevilaqua to Dwight Manfredi

I really dig Frank Grillo, and Bill has some redeeming characteristics, unlike Cal. I don‚Äôt want Bill to get back on Dwight‚Äôs bad side because I‚Äôd like to see him stick around for Tulsa King Season 3.

Bill‚Äôs operation is more interesting than Cal‚Äôs. Cal is a thug (it made me laugh when he referred to Dwight that way), but Bill has family. He and Dwight could work well together, even if it is long distance.

I guess time will tell.

While all of this was happening, Tina was taking control of her own and her family‚Äôs safety.

She is her father‚Äôs daughter. I don‚Äôt understand how he thought she had The General as a father and wouldn‚Äôt be familiar with mob terms. Apparently, he‚Äôs had his head in the sand, too.

Getting a gun is a wise choice, especially since it got her side-by-side with Mitch. I can barely remember her husband, but wasn‚Äôt he a bit of a dolt?

Mitch has a good head on his shoulders, and it will be interesting to see how Dwight reacts as Mitch grows closer to Tina. When Mitch said, ‚ÄúShe‚Äôs a beautiful woman; it was my pleasure,‚Äù Dwight did a double take, but he didn‚Äôt overreact. Maybe that‚Äôs a smidgeon of approval.

And now we get to the ‚ÄúNavigator.‚Äù

Did another Taylor Sheridan show just kill off Michael Beach?? If so, that‚Äôs two in a row where he bit the big one. C‚Äômon, man!

But was he killed? I‚Äôm not an explosions expert, but from what I could see of the front seat of the car, it was relatively unaffected. Well, it‚Äôs as unaffected as a blown-up portion of a car could be.

It‚Äôs possible he‚Äôll survive, if not only because it‚Äôs too choreographed for Beach to die twice across the Taylor Sheridan universe in such short order.

This one will hurt because of how it will affect Tyson. He and his dad have been at odds over his involvement with Dwight for a while now, but this was the first time Mark approved of it.

Tyson was so excited to be able to do something for his dad with no strings attached, and he was even more excited when his dad accepted his gift.

The worst part will be that Tyson eyeballed that white car before and didn‚Äôt pay enough attention to it. That he recognized it in front of the house shows that he did take note.

But why would you take note of a friggin‚Äô Prius? What self-respecting bad guy would be caught dead in one? It makes me wonder if this isn‚Äôt some sort of one-off targeting that has nothing to do with the current situation.

Undoubtedly, Tyson will be beating himself up for his part in what happened to his dad. This will be where the rubber meets the road. Any sweetness that remained in Tyson might be gone due to this tragedy.

He wanted to step up, and this will push him even further toward that end.

Unfortunately, things are only getting more dangerous as time goes on, so he‚Äôll be stepping up at a perilous time ‚Äî assuming Dwight lets him step up under the circumstances.

Who put the hit on Dwight? Was it Jackie without Cal‚Äôs assistance? It didn‚Äôt seem there was enough time for Cal, Bill, or Chickie to make the call. Bill and Chickie are still reeling from the results of the sit-down, and Cal is generally unwilling to kill.

Where does this shocking turn take us now? If you‚Äôve been enjoying Tulsa King this season, please drop me a comment below to share your thoughts.
